CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Could the close working cooperation with Muslim nations and the American Muslim community be more effective in providing intelligence if Donald's rhetoric did not alienate and push them away?
Can you provide evidence that Donald's dismissive attitude towards Muslim nations and communities has led to increased cooperation and intelligence sharing from these regions?
If we're seeking intelligence from Muslim-majority nations and communities, does that not undermine the very rhetoric that Donald has used to alienate and push away the American Muslim community?
If the American Muslim community can provide valuable intelligence to counter terrorism, why does Donald's rhetoric towards them continue to be alienating and push them away?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: What if creating a society that relies on the wealthy paying their fair share and closing corporate loopholes causes a significant increase in tax revenue, which could then be used to fund affordable child care and debt-free college, thereby affecting the decision-making process of the next generation?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the president's ability to "shoulder the immense, awesome responsibilities of the presidency" is solely determined by their ability to "put into action the plans that will make your life better"?

If corporate executives who contribute to the profits are entitled to share in them, why should the working-class individuals who are crucial to generating those profits be denied benefits like paid family leave and affordable healthcare?
If Clinton claims she'll make life better for Americans, does she imply that her policies will somehow be more beneficial than those of her opponent?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: Would the adoption of Donald's policies, which include the notion that climate change is a hoax, potentially cause the US to become the clean-energy superpower of the 21st century?
Do you, Mr. Clinton, have any scientific evidence or expert opinion to support the claim that you are the only one who can ensure the US becomes the clean-energy superpower of the 21st century?
If a nation's economy can recover from a $13 trillion loss in family wealth, why would a person's ability to recover from a loss of their home be any less significant?

If we've come back from the abyss despite the devastating economic losses, can we justify reverting to policies that failed us in the first place, especially when independent experts have scrutinized and rejected those same policies?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: If NATO invokes Article 5 in response to a threat, do they also invoke it when a non-member state, like Iran, is suspected of developing nuclear capabilities?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms the claim that the 28 nations of NATO invoked Article 5 only once, specifically after 9/11?

If the 28 nations of NATO invoked Article 5 in response to a perceived threat from a non-member country, why should it be assumed that the US should not invoke similar collective defense in response to perceived threats from countries like Russia or China?

If the United States and its allies invoked Article 5 of NATO after 9/11, but have yet to invoke it in response to Iran's nuclear program, does this not indicate a double standard in the application of NATO's collective defense commitment?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Does imposing sanctions on Iran without international cooperation and negotiation lead to more effective and less costly outcomes?

Do you have any evidence that suggests your diplomatic efforts in the case of Iran were solely responsible for the successful nuclear deal, rather than a combination of factors including international pressure and negotiations?
If imposing sanctions on Iran through a coalition with Russia and China was effective, would using the same diplomatic approach to address other global conflicts be considered effective?

If Clinton's past diplomatic efforts involving sanctions were successful in halting Iran's nuclear program without military action, then why would the same approach be ineffective in dealing with North Korea?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's temperament cause him to be ill-prepared to handle the pressures of the presidency?
Do you think the former president's personal opinions about temperament are relevant to a commander-in-chief's ability to make informed decisions?
If Clinton is unfit to be a commander-in-chief due to her temperament, does that not also disqualify her from being a role model for women in leadership positions?
If he can't handle being criticized, how can he possibly lead the nation in the face of international criticism?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: If his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons becomes a cause, then what would be the potential effect on global security?
Does the President's concern about nuclear threats being a "number-one threat" imply that his administration's nuclear policies are not a contributing factor to the global threat?

If nuclear weapons are considered a top threat due to the potential for catastrophic damage, would the threat posed by climate change, which also has devastating consequences, not be considered equally alarming?
If the nuclear threat is the number-one threat we face in the world, should we not hold leaders accountable for their cavalier attitudes towards nuclear weapons?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: What if the description of the problem is one that will cause the politician to be perceived as ineffective in addressing the issue?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that women have a stronger preference for monogamy than men, as implied by your statement?
If one can describe a social issue with a phrase like "the problem," does that imply a shared understanding of systemic injustices between her and a white person?
If he did such a great job making peace, why do we need sanctions to pressure North Korea into stopping its violent threats?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: If the Iranian facilities that Clinton is referring to are indeed a result of his deal, would his lack of an alternative plan not undermine his ability to lead the world with strength and in accordance with his values?
Does the president's approach of withholding a specific plan to defeat ISIS while claiming it's a secret plan undermine the trust of the people and the international community?
Does the lack of a concrete plan to defeat ISIS undermine the credibility of a leader who claims to be able to "make decisions that will further peace and prosperity"?

If his deal with Iran has been successful in giving us access to facilities we never had before, does that not demonstrate a capability to make tough decisions, which should be a foundation for trust in his leadership?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: What if deploying a half a billion more solar panels causes the economic growth to be unstable and affect the overall economic recovery?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that deploying a half a billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid will create a significant enough number of jobs to stimulate the economy?

If building a new modern electric grid is seen as a key component of a strong economy, why is the transition to a clean energy source that powers every home seen as a lesser priority than creating jobs and driving new economic activity?

If the economic benefits of renewable energy and grid modernization are so significant, then why should we prioritize economic growth over addressing the environmental concerns that Clinton's policies are trying to mitigate?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: Does enforcing trade deals and holding people accountable, as you claim, have a direct effect on increasing American exports to countries like China by 50 percent?
Can you explain how your voting record, particularly the CAFTA vote, aligns with your claim that you know how to increase exports and create new jobs?
If holding foreign entities accountable for breaking trade deals is a priority, would not holding domestic entities accountable for similar breaches be equally important?
If Clinton's track record in increasing American exports while secretary of state is so successful, why did he vote against CAFTA, a deal aimed at further expanding international trade?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: What if having been a secretary of state is what causes one to be qualified to be a president?
Do you have a record of any legislation or policy you've implemented as secretary of state that can be considered more significant than your time as a senator?
Does Clinton's claim of having "done a lot" as secretary of state equate to the level of experience and authority as being a president, like Trump's claim of having been a senator?
If he claims he has done a lot as a secretary of state, doesn't that imply he's actually accomplished more than you have as a senator?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on creating new jobs and rising incomes causes the economy to grow at the expense of further increasing the national debt?
Do you have a scientific source that supports your claim that the economy's growth is more closely tied to job creation and investment rather than tax cuts?

If Clinton is prioritizing economic growth through job creation and investments, would this not be analogous to prioritizing social growth through community creation and investments in marginalized communities?
If the economy is indeed a top priority for the country, why would the President's proposed tax cuts add $5 trillion to the debt, potentially undermining the very goal of stimulating the economy?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of a comprehensive plan cause the electorate to question the viability of Clinton's proposed economic policies?

Can you provide evidence from your book, "Stronger Together," or any other scientific source to support the claim that your economic plan would create 10 million jobs while the opposing plan would result in a recession?
If his book is about growth, but his economic plan would lead to a recession, can his plan be considered a viable solution for sustained growth?
If Clinton has written a book about a plan and claims it would create jobs, why does she still assert that her opponent's plan would result in a recession?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: If the wealthy and corporations are not paying their fair share, then why should their gains in the economy be a justification for adding $5 trillion to the debt?
Does your claim that your proposal would not add a penny to the debt align with the Congressional Budget Office's analysis, or is this just a partisan assertion?
If the wealthy and corporations have profited from the economy while paying a lower tax rate than the middle class, would it not be fair for them to bear a greater burden in supporting the country?
If the wealthy and corporations should pay their fair share to support this country, then why would their tax burden not be increased by your proposal?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the 5 percent of the world's population that the US represents might be outweighed by the economic influence of the 95 percent they trade with cause the kind of tax system that rewards work over financial transactions to be a more desirable option?

Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that a "different view" of economic growth, as you described, has historically led to more job creation and rising incomes in the United States?

If the wealthiest 5% of the world's population, including Clinton, are only 5% of the global population, wouldn't their economic policies and investments be more reflective of the global economy rather than just the US economy?
If we are 5 percent of the world's population, shouldn't we prioritize our own economic growth and social welfare over the benefits of a single individual's fortunate life?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: Does believing that helping the wealthy will lead to overall prosperity align with the notion that investing in the middle class is crucial for long-term economic growth?
Do you believe that the notion that helping wealthy individuals is the key to a prosperous economy is a scientifically proven fact or a personal opinion?

If a small-businessman who struggles to make a living by manually printing fabrics can achieve success through hard work, why would a wealthy businessman who inherits wealth and starts with a large sum borrowed from his father not be expected to have a similar work ethic?

If he believes that helping wealthy people is the key to a better economy, then why does his own business, which was initially funded by his father, suggest that family connections rather than hard work are the primary drivers of success?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of repatriation, bringing back of money that's stranded overseas causes a decrease in corporate tax revenue?

Do you have any scientific sources or data that support the claim that repatriation of money stranded overseas would be triggered solely by changes in corporate tax rates, as opposed to other factors?

If corporate tax rates are seen as a key factor in the repatriation of money, why would the absence of changes in those rates, according to Clinton, not be a significant obstacle in achieving that repatriation?
If the President's proposal is meant to bring back money stranded overseas, then why is the current tax system not doing that already?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: If the proposed "Trump loophole" would indeed advantage Clinton and the business she does, would that influence her decision to support it?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that supporting a policy would inherently benefit both you and your business?
If a politician like Clinton views a loophole as beneficial, does that not imply that she would also see loopholes in policies that benefit marginalized groups as advantageous?
If Clinton claims that what he has proposed would advantage him and his business, wouldn't that imply he is more interested in personal gain than public benefit?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Would the trickle-down approach advocated by the wealthy individuals Clinton mentioned truly cause a broad-based, inclusive growth in America, or would it merely exacerbate the economic disparities?

Do you have any concrete evidence to support the claim that "trickle-down" economics, as opposed to broad-based, inclusive growth, has historically been more effective in boosting the economy in the United States?

If trickle-down economics, which is often associated with benefiting the wealthy, is seen as ineffective, would policies focused on broad-based, inclusive growth not be a more effective approach to addressing the economic issues Clinton mentioned?
If trickle-down economics has historically led to the economic problems Clinton mentions, can we truly expect it to drive growth and prosperity this time around?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: Will suppressing moral hazard actually lead to the generation of fool's gold, rather than real wealth?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that moral hazard is a natural and inevitable part of the lending and borrowing process?

If the natural consequences of ignoring moral hazard lead to the creation of "fool's gold," would the financial industry's suppression of these consequences not resemble a form of financial "smoke and mirrors"?
If the wealth generated by ignoring moral hazard is indeed "fool's gold," then how can we justify the harm caused by its potential collapse?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: If the life-threatening reactions from peanut exposure can be triggered through contact or inhalation, rather than just consumption, does this not justify a complete ban on peanuts in airline products rather than just restricting their presence on certain flights?

Do you have any scientific data or research that supports the claim that the presence of peanuts on airlines poses a significant enough risk to warrant a complete ban, considering the prevalence of food options available on flights?

If the airline industry is taking steps to mitigate peanut exposure through buffer zones, why would a complete ban of peanut products not be considered a more comprehensive solution to protect passengers with life-threatening allergies?

If you're a physician who has dedicated a website to supporting the food-allergic community, do you think your professional expertise and advocacy for allergy sufferers justify the drastic measure of banning peanut products on all airlines?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: What if the hostility in the debate is causing the audience to become disillusioned with the entire political process, thereby affecting their willingness to participate in future elections?
Do you think the tone of the GOP debates accurately reflects the values and principles that you believe the Republican party should represent?
Does the comparison of the GOP debates to a family argument, where the goal is to alienate the opposing side, accurately reflect the tone and outcome of the debates?

If the GOP debates are indeed as hostile as you describe, does that not suggest a lack of civility and decorum that could negatively impact the image of the party, potentially affecting its chances in the election?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: Should the severity of a child's peanut allergy cause their parents to question whether their future job aspirations should be prioritized over their immediate health risks?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that a child's peanut allergy is a disability that should automatically disqualify them from pursuing a career that requires frequent air travel?

If someone's ability to breathe air or eat food without risk is considered a disability, would a person's ability to travel by air without risking their life due to a severe food allergy also be considered a disability?
If a child's life is at risk from being exposed to airborne peanuts, should we not prioritize his safety over his future career aspirations?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: Would requiring airlines to reserve seating blocks for peanut-allergic passengers cause a significant increase in the overall cost of flying, thereby affecting the airline industry's ability to operate?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that requiring airlines to reserve seating blocks for peanut-allergic passengers is a more effective and necessary measure than simply advising them to carry "rescue" medication and wear protective gear?

If airlines require passengers to forgo their right to eat peanuts to accommodate allergy sufferers, shouldn't they also be required to accommodate passengers with rescue medication needs, considering the risk to their health is just as significant?

If the airline industry has successfully accommodated passengers with disabilities, then why should peanut allergy sufferers be forced to take extraordinary measures to avoid a risk that is, in reality, relatively rare?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If the fact that the DOJ determined an assault weapons ban won't address homicide rates in the US is true, then how can Bernie's proposal for an assault weapons ban be considered a viable solution to the country's problems?
Do you have a scientific study or data that supports the claim that Bernie Sanders is not intelligent?

If the effectiveness of a decade-old DOJ study is a valid argument against gun control, wouldn't the effectiveness of a decades-old study on the impact of European hair standards also be a valid argument against societal beauty standards?
If the DOJ has already determined that an assault weapons ban won't address homicide rates in the US, why is Bernie advocating for it?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Does the unconstitutional application of the "Stop-and-frisk" policy disproportionately affect the rights and freedoms of black and Hispanic young men?
Does the stop-and-frisk policy in New York disproportionately target black and Hispanic young men based on empirical data or anecdotal evidence?
If stop-and-frisk targeted black and Hispanic young men, does that not indicate a systemic bias that would be similar to the profiling of a group based on their race?

If stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional, doesn't that imply that the practice inherently targets certain demographics, such as black and Hispanic young men, and isn't that a form of systemic racism?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: Does the current policy on first use of nuclear weapons lead to a more stable and secure America?
Do you think the current US nuclear policy on first use is morally justifiable, considering the potential consequences for global stability and national security?
If the United States' nuclear policy is seen as a cornerstone of its security, would changing it be analogous to altering the fundamental principles of its national identity?

If the President's consideration of changing the policy on first use of nuclear weapons could lead to a reduction in global nuclear threats, then why would maintaining the current policy continue to prioritize American security over global security?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of transparency about the potential president's financial obligations and business conflicts not undermine the democratic process and the ability of Americans to make informed decisions?
Don't you think that the public's right to know about potential conflicts of interest is more significant than the personal decision to release tax returns?
If a president's personal financial history can be scrutinized to ensure there are no conflicts of interest, why should a politician's tax returns be exempt from public scrutiny?
If nominees have released their returns for decades to maintain transparency, shouldn't the president also release their tax returns to uphold the same standard of accountability?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: If Helen believes families need help, do her views on intervening in their lives contradict her stance on not imposing "the right sort of levels" on families she considers to be terrorising communities?
Do you consider the level of aggression and violence within some families as a sufficient reason to justify state intervention without considering the root causes of their behavior?
If families who require help and intervention are considered deserving of aid, why would those exhibiting high levels of aggression and violence not be deserving of the same assistance?
If you believe that some families need intervention, then do you think it's inconsistent that you wouldn't apply similar levels of support to those living with aggression and violence?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that some current presidential candidates support providing healthcare coverage to undocumented immigrants cause their popularity among xenophobic voters to decrease?
Do you have any evidence that supports the claim that xenophobic sentiments should be equated with policy positions on healthcare access for undocumented immigrants?
If illegal immigrants were receiving the same rights and benefits as citizens, would that not make them essentially the same as citizens?
If they're advocating for illegal immigrants to get healthcare, why can't they support the undocumented workers who contribute to the country's economy?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if the CBP screening requirement causes delays that lead to passengers deplaning, then why not allow passengers to deplane during gate holds without requiring them to remain in the immediate area?
Do you have any evidence or experience as a military member that deplaning during gate holds without CBP screening is a viable and safe option for all airlines and classes of aircraft?

If airlines can allow passengers to deplane during gate holds, why can't the CBP screening process be similarly expedited to allow passengers to proceed without screening, given its conceptual similarity?
If airlines are required to make a legal commitment (contract of carriage), should passengers not also have a contractually guaranteed right to deplane during tarmac delays?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's decision to charge exorbitant fees for carrying pets onboard is causing passengers to prioritize their pets' comfort over their own health and safety due to the lack of adequate space for in-flight exercises?

Do you consider the airline's charging for pet fees as a discriminatory practice that disproportionately burdens passengers who wish to travel with their animals, while also addressing the health concerns related to seat size and configuration as a priority?

If airline companies are prioritizing passenger health by providing exercise instructions in-flight, why should they be allowed to charge for carry-on pet fees, which can be seen as a health issue, yet not address the health issue of seat size and configuration?
If the airline charges exorbitant fees for carrying pets onboard, shouldn't they also be held responsible for ensuring passengers have enough space to prevent deep vein thrombosis?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: What if banning peanut and tree nut products on flights would cause the airline industry to lose millions of dollars in revenue, affecting the jobs of thousands of people?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the risk of anaphylaxis from peanuts or tree nuts is sufficient to justify a blanket ban on these products in air travel?

If a parent's child having a life-threatening allergy to peanuts is a valid reason to ban peanut products on flights, wouldn't a parent's child having a life-threatening allergy to other potential allergens also warrant a ban on those products?
If banning peanuts and tree nuts on flights would save lives, why not also consider banning other common allergens, like shellfish, that pose a similar risk to passengers?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the politician can't talk about everything in their plan cause the public to question the politician's credibility?
Do you have any evidence or scientific research that supports the claim that politicians' public statements often lack concrete plans, as you seem to suggest?
Does the lack of specificity in the politician's plan make it comparable to the empty promises of a website with unverified claims?
If his plan is all there, why does he claim he can't talk about everything in it?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: What if the airline industry's lack of self-monitoring causes the variable and sometimes inaccurate quality of information from airline customer service departments to manifest and affect the psychological effects and risks associated with flying?

Do you believe that the airline industry's self-regulation can effectively mitigate the risks of inaccurate information and psychological trauma for passengers, despite the variability in customer service quality?

If airline customer service departments are so unreliable that they can cause significant psychological harm and risk of death, why should they be trusted to self-regulate the industry without external oversight?
If airlines are unable to provide accurate information, how can they be trusted to ensure the safety of their passengers?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: Do the moderators' reluctance to discuss a compromise position reflect a cause that could lead to the tyranny of the majority in the context of minority interests and needs?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the notion that individuals who object to accommodations have a pre-existing bias against researchers, despite having access to full-text publications?

If the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology and other medical associations publish studies that are dismissed by those who have access to full text, what does that say about the legitimacy of their concerns?

If the opponents of accommodations are aware of studies published in reputable medical journals and have access to full text, why do their preconceived biases against the researchers and their conclusions still prevail?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: Would the presence of peanut allergens in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin cause an increase in the number of reported anaphylactic reactions on commercial airliners?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings, considering the findings of the study you mentioned?

If the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings, would it not be reasonable to assume that the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut dust or oil is minimal, and therefore, the argument for living in a bubble is unfounded?

If peanut allergens can indeed be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners, why should we assume the presence of peanuts in the recirculated air poses a significant risk to passengers with peanut allergies?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If the supposed health risks of peanuts on airplanes are merely a product of anxious parental fears, then why should the airline industry be pressured to restrict peanut distribution?
Do you have any scientifically valid evidence that supports the claim that peanuts are a "public health menace" equivalent to tobacco smoking?

If a rare medically diagnosed allergy to peanuts is a valid reason to restrict one's entire life, would the same reasoning also justify restricting the lives of people with a diagnosed allergy to air travel?
If peanuts are as nutritious and beneficial as you claim, then why do you advocate for their restriction on airplanes rather than promoting education and awareness about actual peanut allergies?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: Would the practice of airlines and some ticket sellers using the tactic of baiting customers with low prices and then switching to higher prices not be a form of bait and switch that could cause consumer distrust and ultimately affect their decision to use those services?
Do you consider the airline's practice of listing separate taxes as a form of Bait and Switch, which you claim is illegal, to be a deceptive business tactic?
If airlines can be accused of employing "bait and switch" tactics with their pricing, would the same tactics be considered deceptive when applied by retail businesses?
If airlines charge customers different prices on the same day, isn't that essentially equivalent to bait and switch, which is an illegal practice?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: Does the notion that social progress comes from wealthy individuals, rather than solely from the poor, justify the significant influence of the wealthy in shaping societal policies?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the primary responsibility for social progress lies with wealthy individuals rather than addressing systemic economic issues?
If the wealthy are capable of driving social progress through investments, why are they not held accountable for perpetuating inequality through consumer credit rather than productive investments?
If the banks are indeed capable of making a positive impact through investments, why do they continue to prioritize consumer credit over socially beneficial loans?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: If the policy of providing sub-prime mortgages was a deliberate political strategy, would that make the economic crisis that followed a more inevitable consequence?
Do you think the notion that economic realities can be ignored or downplayed is a more effective strategy for policymakers than acknowledging the true state of the economy?
If the individuals who benefited from the sub-prime mortgage crisis are now suffering from it, does that not imply that the economic system is flawed?

If your argument is that the economic policies were a form of cover-up, then shouldn't you be advocating for more transparency and accountability rather than simply stating that money doesn't grow on trees?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: If the secrecy surrounding Clinton's tax returns might indicate a lack of transparency, does this potentially damage his credibility as a leader?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that hiding tax returns is a definitive indicator of being uncharitable?

If releasing tax returns for 40 years is a standard practice for presidential candidates, why would a 40-year-old American citizen be expected to have a similar transparency with their tax information?
If releasing tax returns has been a standard practice for nearly 40 years, why does Clinton imply that Trump's failure to release his returns is unusual or noteworthy?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: Does the persistence of racial determinants in various aspects of life, such as education and law enforcement, ultimately cause a lack of trust between communities and the police?

Do you believe that race being a significant challenge in our country, as you've described, would be more effectively addressed through policy changes rather than solely through law enforcement training and community trust-building?
If race determines the quality of education and treatment in the criminal justice system, would it not also determine the likelihood of police using excessive force against communities of color?

If restoring trust between communities and the police is essential, does prioritizing reforming the criminal justice system without addressing the systemic issues that perpetuate racial disparities in policing and education truly address the root of the problem?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: Would the lack of addressing the plague of gun violence contribute to a lack of trust between communities and law enforcement?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that gun violence is a "plague" rather than a social issue, specifically in the context of the leading cause of death of young African-American men?

If the police are expected to "respect the communities" and "tackle the plague of gun violence" that disproportionately affects young African-American men, would the communities not be expected to hold their own leaders and community members accountable for similar issues?
If CLINTON's platform is intended to remedy the problems in the criminal justice system, does that imply that the current system is fundamentally flawed and in need of drastic reform?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: Does the negative portrayal of black communities by Donald Trump, as described by Clinton, cause a rise in violent crime, or is it just a coincidence that it decreased despite his policies?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the decrease in violent crime in 1991 can be attributed solely to community policing rather than other factors such as socioeconomic changes or law enforcement policies?

If Clinton views stop-and-frisk as ineffective and unconstitutional, why does she still support community policing that has been criticized for similar issues of racial bias and mass incarceration of young POC?
If Clinton praises the progress of community policing, why does she also mention that it led to the incarceration of many young African-American and Latino men for nonviolent offenses?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: What if systemic racism in the criminal justice system causes young African-American men to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated at a higher rate than young white men, does this contribute to the lack of second chance programs and the proliferation of private prisons?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the notion that young African-American men are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated than young white men in the absence of systemic racism?

If systemic racism can be addressed in the criminal justice system by diverting people from incarceration, wouldn't addressing the systemic racism in the hiring and promotion processes of law enforcement agencies also be necessary?

If we're acknowledging systemic racism in our criminal justice system, does that imply we should also address the systemic inequalities in our gun laws, which disproportionately affect certain demographics?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: What if the ineffective approaches to community policing, as implied by the mayor's mention of what "did not have the kind of impact that we would want", cause the neighborhoods to become less safe?

Do you, Mr. Clinton, have any empirical evidence to support the claim that the collaboration between communities, faith communities, businesses, and police has been the sole factor in reducing crime in New York, or is this a speculative assertion?

If New York's approach to community policing, which has been deemed effective, is considered a model for the nation, why would it not be used to address the systemic issues faced by other communities, rather than solely relying on the opinions of politicians?
If New York has done an excellent job in reducing violence, then why should we assume other cities can't achieve similar results without the same level of community engagement and collaboration?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: Do the tax policies and actions of those who "rooted for the housing crisis" cause the economic collapse of the Great Recession?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that Donald Trump was one of the individuals who actively contributed to the housing crisis?
If the wealthy's tax policies were a primary cause of the Great Recession, would their own self-interest in a housing crisis not indicate a self-serving motive in the current economic turmoil?
If the economic crisis was largely caused by tax policies, does that imply that the current economic policies are not doing enough to prevent similar crises?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: What if Russia's cyber attacks, facilitated by Putin, cause a significant increase in the vulnerability of the United States' cybersecurity infrastructure?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that Vladimir Putin's actions are the most concerning and troubling aspect of cyber security challenges facing the next president?
If Putin is allowing cyber attackers to hack into government and personal files, does this not resemble state-sponsored terrorism?

If cyber security and cyber warfare are indeed one of the biggest challenges facing the next president, then does the fact that Russia has already demonstrated a capability to hack into government and personal files justify the notion that the US should also be more vigilant about its own cybersecurity vulnerabilities?

CLINTON_176_2.input:
CLINTON: "we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information
We need to make it very clear—whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else—the United States has much greater capacity
we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information
 we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have
We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare
we will defend the citizens of this country
 the Russians need to understand that
 they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do
I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans
That is just unacceptable"

aimwill_178.input:

ambersky_145.input:
ambersky: "I agree with chartley81.
My child has a right to live.
What about the fact that other things have been banned on airlines
I think you can survive not eating peanuts for a few hours,
but my son may not survive the flight if you decide to touch the armrest with a peanut oil covered hand and then he touches it.
yes there are always risks
but banning it lessens that risk to an extent."

cqs.cq: If allowing peanuts on airlines increases the risk of a child's peanut allergy-related death, then shouldn't the potential harm to a few individuals outweigh the inconvenience to the majority?
