SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.
Here is an excerpt from the proposed rule:
"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that airlines have already implemented flight status notifications, driven by customer demand, contradict your claim that the current state of air transit affairs is detrimental to both passengers and profits?

Can you provide a scientific source or empirical evidence that supports the claim that airlines only provide flight status notifications due to customer demand, rather than as a result of their own business interests?

If airlines are incentivized to provide timely and accurate flight information to satisfy customer demand, does this not imply that passengers are indeed benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs?

If airlines are indeed benefiting from customer satisfaction by providing timely flight information, then why do you claim that neither passengers nor profits are benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: Would blanket policies on allowing minors to fly alone on airplanes cause them to be more or less prepared to handle the challenges of traveling without adult supervision?
Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that parents are better equipped to make decisions about their children's travel capabilities than airlines?
Would a one-size-fits-all policy regarding minors flying alone on airplanes not be analogous to a one-size-fits-all policy regarding age requirements for voting?
If SofieM's argument is that parents know their children better than airlines do, does that not imply that blanket policies on this topic are inherently paternalistic?

TRUMP_101.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: What if deleting 33,000 e-mails causes Trump to be more secretive about his own dealings?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that women's behavior regarding email deletion is comparable to or worse than men's behavior?
If Trump's lack of transparency and secrecy over his emails is seen as non-negotiable, why is Clinton's deletion of 33,000 emails not also considered non-negotiable?
If Trump claimed that something is "not negotiable," then does that imply that he's unwilling to compromise on any aspect of the issue?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: Would a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes be more effective in preventing allergic reactions than the current, inadequate measures airlines have in place?
Do you believe that the risks associated with airborne nut dust outweigh the convenience of allowing passengers to bring and eat nuts on planes?

If airlines claim to offer a "nut-free zone" on planes but still allow passengers to bring and consume nuts, why would that not be considered a misleading and inadequate solution for individuals with airborne nut allergies?

If airlines can provide 'nut-free' zones on planes, then why can't they also provide a 'peanut-free' zone that effectively protects passengers like you from airborne nut allergies, rather than just advising passengers to bring their own peanuts?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: If airlines can't stop passengers from eating nuts on their flights, do they not have a responsibility to take a more active role in preventing potential allergic reactions from affecting their passengers?

Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that allowing passengers to bring and eat nuts on flights is a more significant concern than serving nuts due to the airline's advance notice?
If airlines can restrict the serving of nuts on flights, why should passengers not be allowed to have their own 'nut-free' flights if they choose to bring their own food, including nuts?
If airlines can't stop passengers from eating nuts on flights, shouldn't they also be able to prevent the serving of nuts in the first place?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: Would the proposed auction system, offering bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat, cause the airlines to more effectively manage overbooking and reduce the need for compensation?
Do you agree that a credit card credit, as proposed by Julian Simon, would be a more effective and equitable way to compensate passengers for bumping than the current system of check or cash?

If airlines are required to offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat, would this not imply that passengers should have a mandatory option of cash payment, similar to a credit card credit?

If airlines can offer a gradually rising reward for bumped passengers, why can't they simply provide a higher mandatory compensation to prevent overbooking and avoid arbitrary unfairness to certain travelers?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: Would the increased costs of customer dissatisfaction and better-informed flight scheduling decisions, caused by auctioning airline seats, ultimately lead to a reduction in the airlines' financial results?

Do you have any scientific evidence or studies that support the claim that airlines' auctioning off seats to passengers who are involuntarily denied boarding can more accurately price the delay and reduce customer dissatisfaction?

Would the airline industry's current system of overbooking and involuntary denial of boarding be considered analogous to a system where passengers are forced to bid for their right to fly, effectively creating a market for delay and dissatisfaction?

If the airlines can more accurately price the delay through an auction, then why do we need involuntary denials of boarding when they could be avoided by the carriers facing the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If airlines charge passengers fees to change their itineraries due to personal circumstances, should they not also be required to compensate passengers for the inconveniences caused by their own schedule changes?

Do you have any evidence from the airline industry that suggests airlines are not responsible for compensating passengers when their flight schedules change after booking, despite passengers incurring significant changes to their travel plans?

If airlines can charge passengers to change their flight schedules for personal reasons, would it not be logical for airlines to compensate passengers for the inconvenience caused by their own schedule changes?

If airlines are required to pay passengers to change their flight schedules due to personal circumstances, why shouldn't passengers be entitled to receive compensation and satisfactory alternate travel arrangements when airlines change their flight schedules without prior notice?

elizwestley_222.input:
elizwestley: "A peanutfree table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it.
Risk of exposure is reduced
which is not as good as eliminated but is better than full exposure.
I see the parallel with these flight proposals.
Ban peanut products.
Yes, people will "sneak" them.
However, the risk will still be reduced over the nothing that we are doing now."

cqs.cq: If a ban on peanut products is likely to be circumvented by people "sneaking" them, does this still justify the claim that the risk will be reduced over the current situation?

Do you have any scientific evidence or studies to support the claim that a partial exposure to peanut butter on a table is significantly better than full exposure in terms of reducing the risk of anaphylaxis?
If peanut products are still present despite the ban, would a table with smears of peanut butter on it not still pose a risk of exposure similar to the current situation?
If a table with smears of peanut butter is considered less safe than a completely clean table, shouldn't we consider banning peanut products as a middle ground rather than doing nothing?

elizwestley_68.input:
elizwestley: "I've registered my son on a flight as peanutallergic and had the attendant try to hand him a bag of peanuts.
Flight personnel need more education on this."

cqs.cq: What if flight attendants are not adequately trained on handling peanut allergies, does this cause a significant risk of an allergic reaction affecting the passenger's health?
Do you have any training or evidence that suggests flight attendants are more likely to prioritize allergen education over the accuracy of passenger information?
If flight personnel are trained to handle peanut allergies, wouldn't they also be trained to handle other life-threatening conditions, such as severe food allergies?
If flight personnel are trained to handle medical emergencies, why are they not trained to handle a potentially life-threatening food allergy like peanut allergy?

golff4fun_155.input:
golff4fun: "I think it's important to stress the real reason that aircraft is not returning to the gate.
Once the aircraft pulls away from the jetway, the crew is on the clock.
They are not being paid while sitting at a gate.
And 3 hours is too long to keep people on a grounded airplane."
 < this message is answering to > 
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if allowing passengers to deplane during gate holds would cause a significant increase in the likelihood of security breaches, which would ultimately affect the safety of the aircraft and its crew?

Do you have a personal experience or scientific evidence to support the claim that deplaning without CBP screening is a viable option, similar to your military experience, and can be safely implemented in a commercial airline setting?
If passengers can deplane during gate holds without CBP screening, would airlines and airports still be responsible for ensuring their safety and well-being while they wait?
If passengers can deplane during gate holds, then why should they not be allowed to deplane during tarmac delays that are equally inconvenient and lengthy?

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If the airline's decision to charge more for checked luggage based on weight is a cause of public discontent, what effect does this have on the airline's public image and customer loyalty?

Do you have any scientific evidence or studies that support the claim that airlines should be allowed to charge passengers based on their weight, rather than treating all passengers equally regardless of their weight?
If airlines charge extra fees for checked luggage based on weight, why should the fee be tied to the passenger's weight rather than the actual weight of the luggage?
If airlines can charge extra fees based on weight, wouldn't that imply they should also charge based on age, since age also affects a person's ability to carry or check a bag?

grayk47__302.input:
grayk47: " you give an illegally (as in you stole it) acquired firearm to a friend to use responsibly
that person accidentally shoots someone
who should be blamed
Both should be held responsible
This is the same case for Snowden
he gave illegally acquired papers that he stole, to the Times in the hopes that they would responsible with it
They failed in that
a terrorist group was able to use the exposed information to alter their plans
It's cut and dry"

cqs.cq: If the person you gave the illegally acquired firearm to had no prior knowledge or understanding of how to use it responsibly, should you still be held equally responsible for the consequences of their actions?
Do you believe the legal culpability of Snowden mirrors the criminal liability of the person who received the illegally acquired firearm, considering the consequences of their actions?
If a person who receives a stolen firearm from someone and uses it to cause harm, should the person who stole the firearm also be held accountable for the consequences?
If giving a stolen firearm to someone who then causes harm can be considered irresponsible, then isn't giving stolen information to the press also a form of irresponsible action?

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: If airlines are able to implement precautions for passengers with tree nut allergies, would it not be more practical to hold the individual with the allergy or their caretaker responsible for their own safety rather than relying on the airlines to bear the burden?
Don't you think the airlines' responsibility to provide precautions for passengers with severe tree nut allergies outweighs the potential inconvenience of passengers with peanut allergies?
If airline passengers with severe food allergies are expected to take responsibility for their safety, why should airlines be held accountable for accommodating their needs?
If airlines can take precautions to accommodate passengers with peanut allergies, why can't we also take similar precautions to accommodate those with tree nut allergies?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: What if the allergist's supposed plague of food allergies being the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists causes parents like you to overestimate the severity of their children's allergies?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the airline industry's inability to guarantee a peanut-free flight is comparable to the risk of a child having a severe milk allergy?

If a doctor who has a child with severe life-threatening allergies to milk, peanuts, and eggs can't guarantee a peanut-free flight, why can't airlines guarantee a peanut-free flight, and why should the airline's inability to do so justify the doctor's concerns about the potential risks to her child?

If your child's allergies are severe enough to warrant epinephrine and emergency medical assistance, then why do you still advocate for airline staff to serve peanuts, which you acknowledge can be a potential threat to the safety of passengers like your child?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Would the restrictive policies you're advocating for regarding peanuts on airlines potentially cause more harm by inadvertently driving the sale of peanuts underground, making it harder to track and monitor potential allergen reactions?

Do you have any peer-reviewed studies or medical literature that support your claim that peanut reactions can be life-threatening through contact or inhalation without actual consumption of the product?

If a doctor who has a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy is allowed to sway airline policy, would that not undermine the credibility of medical expertise in public health decisions?

If peanuts are a life-threatening allergen, why does your online support forum, which you claim has 3000 members, not include information about how to safely manage and minimize the risk of peanut exposure on flights, rather than advocating for a blanket ban?

howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.
Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."
 < this message is answering to > 
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' inability to provide adequate precautions for passengers with severe allergies causes a significant increase in allergic reactions among travelers?
Do you think it is more reasonable for airlines to bear the responsibility of accommodating passengers with severe allergies, rather than requiring individuals to take precautions?
If tree nut allergy reactions are comparable to peanut allergy reactions in severity, why should the airline industry's response not be comparable in terms of responsibility?
If airlines have precautions in place, wouldn't that be a more effective solution than relying on the general population to take precautions?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Would the prevalence of peanuts in the environment cause a significant increase in the likelihood of a fatal peanut allergy reaction?
Can you provide a scientific study or medical evidence to support the claim that peanuts are so ubiquitous that someone with a severe allergy should never leave the house?
If peanuts are so nutritious and beneficial, why should they be avoided by those with a severe allergy, but not be considered beneficial for everyone else?
If peanuts are so nutritious and universally enjoyed, then why should the lives of people with actual medically diagnosed severe allergies be restricted by avoiding peanuts everywhere?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: If the presence of peanuts on flights is proven to cause severe reactions in individuals like you, then why should airlines prioritize the comfort of peanut advocates over the health and well-being of those with peanut allergies?

Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that a buffer zone or complete prohibition of peanuts on flights would be ineffective in preventing a life-threatening reaction for individuals with severe peanut allergies?

If people with peanut allergies have a legitimate concern about in-flight peanut dust, would it be logical to compare their situation to smokers' concerns about secondhand smoke, considering both involve airborne allergens and reactions?
If the presence of peanuts on flights poses a life-threatening risk to some passengers, should airlines prioritize passenger safety by banning peanuts entirely, just as they did with smoking?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: If the peanut allergy prevalence doubles from 1997 to 2002 and continues to increase, then why should peanuts be allowed on planes, posing a risk to the lives of individuals with life-threatening allergies?

Do you have a scientific study that supports your claim that peanuts pose a unique risk on planes, considering the effectiveness of EpiPens and other medical interventions in preventing anaphylactic reactions?
If peanuts are a deadly risk to people with allergies, would flights with peanuts not be considered a hazardous product?

If peanut allergies can be life-threatening and even the slightest microscopic amount of peanuts can cause an anaphylactic reaction, should we not prioritize passenger safety by banning the sale and serving of nut products on planes?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of adequate space and ergonomically designed seats in economy class causes passengers to experience back and leg pain, which could lead to long-term health issues and increased medical costs?

Do you have any scientific research or ergonomic studies that support the claim that a 3" wider seat or a pop-up footrest would be more effective in addressing passenger comfort than the current designs, rather than just relying on anecdotal feedback?

If airlines prioritize comfort and ergonomics in their designs, would this not be a more effective way to address the issue of lack of space in economy class seats rather than simply reducing seat size or leg room?
If airlines prioritize profit over passenger comfort, shouldn't they be held accountable for the detrimental effects of their poorly designed seats?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: Would allowing pets to travel in the seat next to their owners, secured by a seat belt, significantly increase the likelihood of passengers choosing to fly with their pets?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that allowing dogs to travel in the cabin is more cost-effective than shipping them in cargo?
If airline passengers are allowed to bring their emotional support animals, why should service animals be treated as mere cargo?
If airlines can charge the same or more for pet cargo as for human tickets, why can't they also provide more convenient and cost-effective options for pet owners like yourself?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: Would the increased media coverage of a previously unknown candidate like Bernie Sanders be the sole cause of his subsequent rise in popularity?

Does the fact that a relatively unknown candidate like Bernie Sanders is receiving significant media attention now, compared to others like O'Malley who were largely ignored, suggest a potential bias in media coverage influencing the perception of their chances at the nomination?
If the media attention given to Bernie Sanders transformed his chances, can the lack of media attention given to Martin O'Malley not have a similar impact on his candidacy?
If Chafee's performance in the debate was indeed a "trainwreck," would it not be more logical for him to be receiving less media attention rather than O'Malley, who seemingly performed better?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: Will the airline's ability to inform passengers every 30 minutes about flight delays cause a significant reduction in anxiety-related issues among passengers?

Do you think informing passengers about flight delays every 30 minutes would be a significant enough solution to alleviate frustration, considering the potential benefits might vary depending on individual anxiety levels and other factors?

If people with anxiety issues can be relieved by being informed regularly about flight delays, wouldn't airlines also have a responsibility to inform passengers about flight delays, regardless of the airport, airline, or destination?

If people with anxiety issues like you find regular updates during delays make a significant difference, shouldn't airlines be required to provide similar updates to all passengers regardless of the length of the delay?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: Would the absence of equal time on privately owned networks for the Green Party or any other minor party's presidential candidates cause their message to be lost to the public entirely?
Do you believe that private networks have a right to discriminate against certain political party candidates in terms of airtime?
If a privately owned news network can limit a major party candidate's access to a debate, why can't a major party limit a minor party candidate's access to the same platform?
If a cable news network isn't a public place, then why should a person who wants to run on the Green Party ticket be denied the opportunity to express their views on it?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: Does the limited debate format to five people unfairly exclude or unfairly prioritize the voices of the remaining 166 candidates who have filed with the FEC?
Do you believe the 171 people who have filed with the FEC should be given the same opportunity to participate in the first debate as the original five, regardless of their ranking or popularity?
If a debate is limited to five people, does that not imply that the remaining 166 individuals who have filed with the FEC are being unfairly excluded from the platform?
If the first debate is limited to five people, does that not inherently imply that the rest of the 171 candidates are not considered worthy of the same opportunity to express themselves?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: Would imposition of common sense regulations truly level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to prioritize profits over passenger needs?

Do you have any evidence from the airline industry itself, or from regulatory bodies, that imposition of common sense regulations has historically resulted in increased costs for airlines, rather than a leveling of the playing field?
Would imposing common sense regulations on the airline industry be analogous to the imposition of regulations in other industries that have led to improved outcomes and fairer competition?
If airline profits are the driving force behind the "race to the bottom," then why do we need passengers to be held hostage to airline interests rather than prioritizing their own needs?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of access to food and drink on a long flight causes passengers to become irritable and affects the airline's overall customer satisfaction?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that passengers should be offered more than just a bag of peanuts and a glass of water on a six-hour delay?
If airline passengers are allowed to deplane and stretch their legs, why would they not be allowed access to more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water during an extended period of sitting?
If passengers are expected to sit for an excessive amount of time, why should the airline not provide more substantial food options beyond a bag of peanuts and a glass of water?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: What if the delay in serving meals causes passengers to experience dehydration, affecting their ability to travel safely?
Don't you think prioritizing passenger access to food and drink over allowing them to move around could potentially be hazardous to their health, just as delaying meal service on a flight?
If passengers are given access to a holding area without food and drink, would it not be analogous to providing them with basic human rights and dignity?
If allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area could provide them with some basic needs, why can't they be given access to food and drink, rather than merely being allowed to move around?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: Would the airlines' practice of bumping passengers based on ticket price or frequent flyer miles undermine the fundamental expectation of a ticket, which is to guarantee a seat from point A to point B?
Do you believe that the fundamental principle of a ticket purchase being a promise of service delivery should take precedence over the airline's revenue management practices?

Would the airline's promise of a seat be considered a form of lottery ticket if the passenger's ticket price doesn't guarantee their travel, similar to a cup of coffee that may or may not contain coffee?
If airline tickets are not lottery tickets, why should passengers be treated as if they are buying a chance to fly rather than a guaranteed service?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' ability to discriminate against lower-fared passengers or "free" passengers and bump them in favor of higher-paying passengers causes them to lose passengers who value their promised seats?

Do you have any scientific evidence or industry data to support the claim that airlines' practices of bumping passengers and charging extra fees are solely driven by a lack of sufficient compensation, rather than other factors such as market demand or operational efficiency?
If airlines can adjust ticket prices after purchase, would they not have a similar ability to adjust seat allocations after passengers have boarded?
If airlines can advertise low fares or "build up your miles" and then bump passengers who paid more, isn't it essentially the same as allowing them to increase ticket prices anytime after purchase?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: Shouldn't airlines like Delta inform passengers with peanut allergies about the presence of peanuts on flights before they pay and board?

Do you have any evidence that Delta Airlines has a clear and transparent policy to inform passengers about peanut presence on flights, especially considering the potential risks for passengers with severe allergies?

If airlines like Delta have a responsibility to inform passengers about potential allergens like peanuts, why would they not have a similar responsibility to disclose the presence of peanuts before passengers pay for a flight?
If airlines like Delta don't inform passengers about potential allergens on their flights, shouldn't they be held accountable for the risks this poses to customers with allergies?

you should go down and take a look at that

TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this

What are we doing
we have to stop the violence
In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years
almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president"

cqs.cq: Does the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police and other law enforcement groups influence the public's perception of the severity of crime in cities like Chicago, rather than the actual crime rates?

If a city that is plagued by violence and lawlessness is referred to as a "war-torn country", does the United States, with its own history of racial tensions and violence, resemble a war-torn country?

If the law and order that you claim to champion is so crucial to a country, then why does the fact that thousands of African-Americans and Hispanics have been killed in inner cities, which you described as "living in hell", not prompt you to take more decisive action?

you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it

cqs.cq: What if the presence of illegal immigrants and their access to guns in Chicago is what causes the high crime rate, which in turn affects the need for stop and frisk policies?

If Mayor Giuliani's "stop and frisk" policy was effective in reducing crime in New York, why wouldn't a similar approach be considered in Chicago, despite Trump's claim that almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed?

 These are very, very good people

If Trump says he has the endorsement of the NRA, doesn't that imply he prioritizes gun rights over national security concerns regarding individuals on watch lists and no-fly lists?

If President Trump believes that leaving troops in Iraq would have prevented the formation of ISIS, wouldn't that imply that the presence of US troops in the region for an extended period would have been a more effective solution than the military intervention that led to the creation of ISIS?

If President Trump believes that leaving troops behind in Iraq would have prevented the formation of ISIS, does he think that leaving troops behind in other countries would be a sufficient solution to prevent the rise of similar extremist groups?

TRUMP_202_1.input:

we should be asking—we're defending them, and they should at least be paying us what they're supposed to be paying by treaty and contract

If Trump is arguing that NATO should focus on terrorism and that the US pays 73% of the cost, does that not imply that NATO's priorities and financial burdens should be reevaluated?

MT_14.input:

MT_45.input:

cqs.cq: What if the lack of sufficient surpluses under that form of capitalism causes a reduction in the flow of money into industrial activities?

ND_23.input:
ND: " I think in the current situation that both savers and borrowers, if you're talking about individual people, are doing extremely badly
many people are unable to make ends meet and are having to take debt out at huge levels of interest

cqs.cq: What if the economic policies and political decisions causing widespread debt and low interest rates for savers don't lead to a fundamental shift in how credit liberalisation is regulated?

Do you believe that solely attributing blame to individual savers and borrowers, rather than addressing systemic economic and political issues, is a more nuanced reflection of the current economic reality?

If savers are penalized for not using their savings due to low interest rates, why should borrowers be blamed for taking out debt at high interest rates when economic policies and political decisions are the root cause of this issue?
If savers are earning nothing in interest, does this not imply that the current economic policies are prioritizing the needs of borrowers over those of savers?

CF_62.input:
CF: "RS: Provide that for our young people

 And I suppose that’s my concern; how do we encourage the young?
It’s not beyond the imagination to imagine the young might get up and go and do something about this, other than kind of sit and wait to be handed something.
Now you’re saying “Provide that for our young people”, and in a way that’s where I’m going."

cqs.cq: What if treating young adults as passive recipients of something actually causes them to become less motivated to take initiative and make decisions about their own futures?

If young adults are expected to take initiative and action, why would providing them with opportunities be seen as a passive act?
If we're encouraging our young people to be active agents of change, then why are we not also empowering them to make decisions rather than just receiving something?

JW_35.input:
JW: "JW has got a rather nuanced view, that the way they're mis-used can have morally damaging consequences
Well, debt is morally neutral in the sense that it can be good to be in debt
 Sometimes it’s a good idea, and sometimes it’s a bad idea
And so I think there’s been broad agreement about that in the discussion so far
The question is why is there too much debt?
 Why are people taking on too much debt?
 this one is the elaboration of the previous question Now,
a lot of people come up with rather glib moral answers: somehow bankers want them to get into excessive debt
 which is a very peculiar idea, when you think that it’s the bankers who aren’t going to get repaid. So it’s a very odd idea
there’s too much debt for the same reason that there are too many unmarried mothers, and for the same reason that you get an overproduction of sheep."

cqs.cq: What if the widespread assumption that bankers are the primary cause of excessive debt actually causes people to overlook the potential consequences of their own financial decisions?
Do you have any evidence from the financial industry that supports the claim that bankers profit from excessive debt, rather than simply providing loans as a neutral service?

If the concept of debt being morally neutral is analogous to the concept of a car being a morally neutral object, would it not be more accurate to say that the car's manufacturer is morally responsible for its misuse rather than the car itself?
If debt is morally neutral and can be good or bad, doesn't the fact that there's too much debt imply that the moral neutrality of debt is being misused?

CLINTON_1_1.input:
CLINTON: "The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we 'll build together

we have to build an economy that works for everyone , not just those at the top
we need new jobs , good jobs , with rising incomes

I want us to invest in your future
jobs in infrastructure , in advanced manufacturing , innovation and technology , clean , renewable energy , and small business
most of the new jobs will come from small business

I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing"

If the economy is supposed to work for everyone, not just those at the top, would that not also imply the need to address systemic disparities and inequalities, rather than just focusing on job creation and profit-sharing?
If we prioritize investing in the future of our citizens, shouldn't we also prioritize addressing the immediate needs of those citizens, especially on their second birthday?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them

I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good

personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: Does the president's words about honoring defense treaties with Japan and South Korea cause the global leaders to view the US as a more reliable ally?

Does Clinton's assertion that "our word is good" in relation to the US's defense treaties with Japan and South Korea imply that she believes her administration's commitment to these treaties is a guarantee, rather than a promise subject to the whims of future administrations?
If a president's words are considered essential to global allies, why would a president's personal character traits be irrelevant to global leaders?

If the reliability of America's word is indeed a crucial factor in maintaining alliances, how can the credibility of the US president be compromised by not taking decisive action against Iran's nuclear program?
